trial_identification.studytitle: Comparing telephone versus mail survey methods with stroke survivors, on response rate, time to response, and completeness.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised trial with stroke survivors to compare telephone to mail survey methods on response rate, time to response and completeness of survey responses.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Research that is not of generic health relevance and not applicable to specific health categories listed above

interventions.interventions: Survey administered by mail. Survey includes questions about readmission, subsequent strokes, and the EQ5D (used to measure the health-related quality of life dimensions of mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression). The survey takes approximately 10 minutes to complete. The Survey is sent with a Reply Paid Envelope; survey must be returned within 2 weeks of receiving it. If not received after this, the survey is re-delivered (maximum of 3 surveys mailed).
interventions.comparator: Survey administered by telephone. Survey includes questions about readmission, subsequent strokes, and the EQ5D (used to measure the health-related quality of life dimensions of mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression). The survey is administered by a health professional, and it takes approximately 10 minutes to complete. Only one survey is administered; three telephone calls to obtain a response are made prior to counting the participant as incomplete.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Response rate: a response is defined as completion of mandatory questions, specifically readmission (yes/no), subsequent stroke (yes/no).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Three months after admission to hospital.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time to response: length of time between contact (by mail or telephone) to obtaining a response.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: time to response assessed from time of contact for followup (at 3 months post-admission) for a period of up to 12 weeks.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Registered case in the Australian Stroke Clinical Registry

trial_design.concealment: Computer generated and allocated online sysetm; allocation is therefore concealed.
trial_design.sequence: Computer generated within the Registry database

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Australian Stroke Clinical Registry Management Committee
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: PO Box M201, Missenden Road, Sydney NSW 2050

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 3, 33-35 Atchison Street, St Leonards NSW 2065

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A prospective randomized trial of the method of follow-up: cases registered in a national registry who were 3-months post-stroke receive the survey by mail or telephone. Data included collection of stroke and re-hospitalisation rates, and health-related quality of life. Response rates, time to response, and completeness of data were compared. Factors potentially associated with the outcome were explored.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: NSW Population and Health Services Research Ethics Committee
